comments.content: Oh, good luck with that!
Get a balance bike, apparently they work miracles. I got one for brody for Xmas....
You can get one for $40 from Walmart...
That must be genetic bc I come to completely losing it too! Let Mom take over.

Pay an older kid in the neighborhood and promise them both ice cream for success.  Brendan learned to tie his shoes because I paid his best friend who the  offered him 1/2 if he learned quickly....24 hrs later shoes are tied both kids made money and got ice cream...winning...lol
The visual of this really cracks me up. Good luck! (Btw, I learned waaay after 6)
Stick to your guns, that's how my dad did it and look at me!  I totally know how to ride a bike.
Go with the balance bike as Megan suggested.  Very popular in our neighborhood which is why we have a bunch of three year olds riding pedal bikes with no training wheels.
Teaching on grass downhill..slightly
Put one training wheel on and one off. That way they still see they are "safe" because the one is still on and are less scared. It has worked for all of mine  :-)  good luck!!

I just remembered another trick of my dad's. Just ask him "you don't want your friends to think you're a wussy do you?" Or try flapping your arms and saying "bok bok bok" like a chicken. Parenting gold courtesy of col jd Counselman.
Towel wrapped under the armpits to hold him up.
How's Bailey doing? ...is she riding training wheel free?  😁  that might help, little competition? .... Then again, maybe not
Remove the pedals and make it a "balance bike" for a week...my Jackson scoots all over line that.  Pretty amazing actually.
Offer a treat for each loop he does!  Caden was all about a mini marshmallow after each loop he did on his bike  :)
I agree stick to your guns. I learned the same way. All about persistence. Sometimes you may have to hurl it 6 or 7 maybe even 10 times.
A small bike you can put feet on ground is how Austin learned
What Paola said.  ;)

Our little neighbor girls came up with the idea to run really fast holding a lollipop while Ellington peddled fast to reach it. Completely dangerous and you like a fool doing it - you even feel slightly guilty for bribing...  but it worked, lol
Hahaha!! Oh the f-bomb!
A second vote for taking off pedals. Helps teach balance. I've taught people in my Burning Man camp that way.
Oh yeah,  Kayne Burk , i kept forgetting to tell you, i know  Stephen Houghton , also.
Let your wife do it.....in a big empty parking lot!
I too the pedals off and let Austyn use it as a scooter for a week or two. Did the trick. Good luck, and remember when he is ready he will do it.
Another vote from me to take the pedals off. The balance bike has worked amazingly for us. And keep the f bombs coming. They always help.
Balance bike! The girls taught themselves to ride a pedal 2 wheeler

description: Stephen Houghton Anyone have advice for teaching a timid 6 year old to ride a bike without training wheels?  Apparently my approach of blowing my serenity, dropping an f bomb, nearly hurling the bike into a patch of cactus, and storming off is ineffective. Kayne Burk Stephen Houghton

Doug Connolly My friend  Stephen Houghton  has built an adult (mature high school and up)  study aid company from the ground up called  Study Sauce . They have group and individual monthly plans available. Stephen would hate for me to tout this, but I don't care: he is a great guy, whip-smart and served honorably as a U.S. Marine. This almost makes up for the fact that he also has Harvard on his resume.

I wish my German shepherd Tia who is at the rainbow bridge had this opportunity. Two of her favorite things..swimming and tennis balls. Maybe this pool exists at the rainbow bridge..it would be her version if pure heaven. 😙
Mark   Andrew   Tara  I just started cracking up because this reminds me of that dog in the water that day we were sitting on the beach trying to save both his tennis  balls hahahahaha

I could really see Cocoa going nuts with all those balls. Too funny. It's a good thing that I woke up at 2:30am and cleaned the bird cage and odds and ends. I have been laughing most of the afternoon on these different sites. Too many people are encouraging my crazy side.

Oh Fiiiiiiooonnnnaaaa!!! we could do this right, like we could really do the pool thing this summer right.  Oh it would be soooo fun and I have enough balls.  Really truly I do....oh I do want to we could couldn't wee.   I'll be good I promise...oh wha ... See More

comments.content: What happened to kids being kids! They don't need all the electronic crap. They should be outside playing, riding bikes, running around. Being kids. Doing what kids are supposed to do. My son is autistic. Do I understand that comment. But I would still ... See More

Great idea! Helps children between ages 3/4 tell time. Plus parents who are involved with their kids can create and monitor chores/rewards. Don't worry, there's no fb so your kids won't be distracted from real life like you are right now. 😝

I would never use this to replace parenting, however, I work with Autistic Youth who need a schedule and reminders. This would be a great tool instead of a Pecs Board and def easier to carry than an IPad. Hmmm!

For all the negative people.. Why's this all mean so much to you if you think they're for lazy parents & for making children even more dumb as someone stated! All those people saying "just let kids be kids" please tell me when is the cut off point for "letting them be kids" when exactly are we meant to break it to them that in the real world you don't have a Slave following you round doing everything for you ... See More
What happens to using plain thinking now kid's need a smart watch to do their thinking for them what next a smart watch to potty train these kids

For children with ADHD or Autism or other unique challenges (read opportunities!) this could be very helpful in enabling them to feel more in control of there day and cut out lots of scraps with parents constantly nagging to get them back on task. Needs to be waterproof though  :)

Imagine a child crying because you changed from one activity to another. Then invision a massive meltdown. If we had another tool to help our kids prepare while you are out and about with a visual we would decrease our own stress. Imagine if you where  ... See More

My son, almost 4, would love this! He has a watch already even though he can't read it because he wants to be just like mom and dad! He tells me what time it is regularly, even though it's just a time he made up. It would be great to have icons so he knew what happened at certain times, wake up, eating, brushing teeth, etc. he would love it.

I dont get what this fuss is about. What's wrong in teaching children to get things done in time? It has nothing to do with not letting them be kids. Playtime may still be playtime, but it's much easier for them to see exactly when it's supposed to finish.

I'm pretty sure a bunch of kids are just going to push the button and carry on with that ever they were doing before without actually doing the "task" it told them to do.  What's wrong with parenting your own kids without technology?  Especially when the parents aren't keeping an eye on them and relying on the app to tell them what their kids are doing

My kids would love these and be more excited to do chores and brush their teeth. It's not about lack of parenting it's about making things they "need" to do" more interesting to get them on a better schedule:)

Anybody that is calling this a lazy option, obviously doesn't have autistic spectrum kids, who could greatly benefit from this to help them gain a little independence without constantly being "babied" by their parents. I think this is a brilliant idea ... See More

This makes everyday chores so much more fun for kids. My 8 yr old son would love this and I would love not yelling and nagging to brush teeth get dressed ect there is nothing negative about this all u old school parents calm the fuk down  😂 😂   ur kids still need to do those everyday things, everyday and if ur child is like mine that winges about everything this just makes it easier.

FFS! Why do we seem to have cotton ball everything. I see this as a tool that can be of use, but not to turn young people into mindless lazy individuals that need to be prompted to undertake basic daily tasks. People need to start being accountable for themselves and stop relying so much on technology to do it for them.
Katie Elizabeth  I feel like Amaiya would love this!
Yet another tool to take away from parents actually parenting. This is stupid. Teach your kids parents, get them away from technology so young. Let them be kids for a change.

This would be a great tool for multiple things. I feel like the biggest would be for those children with short fuses, concentration issues or need a schedule to function well.  I think this would be great to help teach a child responsibility. No, don't ... See More

for children with add and adhd this would be great. my son also suffers from ptsd and explaining simple things to him can break him into a fit, with anger and becoming very upset and can lash out. it is a work in progress and we arr waiting for the rig ... See More
Not good socially. How will these kids learn to take directions from adults when they are older? Or even their teachers?  ... See More

Why don't we all just stop talking to each other altogether?! That's the way it's heading... the amount of technology in children's lives now they are losing the natural life skills of reading body language, how to approach social situations and social cues already.  This contraption will just make children even more antisocial and more like trained monkeys!

I'm sorry, what happened to kids being kids now a days? And not having to worry about electronic devices. Let kids play outside, ride bikes, have water balloon fights and be a kid. This is what parents are for, people!!!! And of course their slogan is "for kids"....that's how they fucking sell it and get you to believe it's made for kids. Jesus Christ....

This is so stupid. What happened to parenting? A 3 year old doesn't understand responsibility. Most kids don't until they start to be teenagers. My child is almost 3 and I have to help brush her teeth. A reminder won't help brush her teeth. This would be good for parents but stop making our children grow up to fast and encouraging parents not to be parents.

This is stupid and sad, just goes to show how far we have come in our urge to control everything while at the same time trying to rid ourselves of more and more responsibility. Trying to force our children into the hectic machinery that our world is before they can even tell the time and taking away their carelessness and freedom even earlier.

This is the most disturbing thing I've seen in a while. I'm not saying kids don't need a routine or schedule, but hell they don't need to worry about it! Where are the parents, guiding them?  Seriously I never even respond to things like this but I truly find this exceptionally disturbing. Let kids be kids and parents be parents.
"In theory this means parents wont have to interact with their kids so much and can pass all responsibility of establishing a daily routine and punctuality to a computer" - great job!
